tutorial.title: Select
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to create a select element to let the user choose from a predefined list of options.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's dive into input elements. These are helpful if we want to give a predefined list of options.

In HTML, we use the select element to create a dropdown list of options for user input.

lessons.title: Input element
lessons.interactiveContent:
We create select elements using the <select> tag.

Make sure to pick <select>, followed by </select>.

lessons.title: Option
lessons.interactiveContent:
Inside the <select> tag, we include <option> tags.

Make sure to pick <option>, followed by English, and finally </option>.

lessons.title: Options
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can include as many options as we want. For every option, we need an opening and closing option tag.

Make sure to pick <option> followed by </option> and then <option>, </option>, <option>, </option>.

lessons.title: Selected
lessons.interactiveContent:
The selected attribute determines the pre-selected option in a dropdown list.

If you don't explicitly set a selected attribute on any of the options, the browser will automatically select and display the first one.

Make sure to type selected.

lessons.title: Select layout
lessons.interactiveContent:
Like buttons, select elements need a <br> tag to place one below another.

Make sure to pick <, followed by br, and finally >.

lessons.title: Naming
lessons.interactiveContent:
Adding a name attribute to your elements is like giving them a name tag at a party â€“ it helps everyone identify them easily.

Make sure to pick countries.

lessons.title: Question #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
How many select elements does this code have?

OneTwo

Make sure to pick One.

lessons.title: Question #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display?

A select element for choosing a category from predefined optionsA select element for adding your favorite category

A select element for choosing a category from predefined options.

lessons.title: Question #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display?

A select element with three option elementsThree select elements next to each another

A select element with three option elements.

lessons.title: Question #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which HTML element do we use to create a drop-down list on a webpage?

selecttable

Make sure to pick select.

lessons.title: Question #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be the default option for a select element if no selected attribute is present?

The first optionThe last option

The first option.

lessons.title: Question #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this code?

The select element is missing its optionsThe select element is missing its closing tag

The select element is missing its options.

lessons.title: Example #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a select element by coding the <select> tag.

Make sure to pick <, followed by select, and finally >.

lessons.title: Example #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let users choose the city they're from by setting the option elements inside the select element in HTML.

Make sure to pick select followed by option and then /option, /select.

lessons.title: Example #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finish the code by adding the opening <option> tag.

Make sure to type <option>.

lessons.title: Example #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a dropdown menu for the user.

Make sure to pick <select>, followed by </select>.

lessons.title: Example #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the select element's name to fruit using name="fruit".

Make sure to type name="fruit".

lessons.title: Getting the value
lessons.interactiveContent:
To access the input from a select element, we need to get the element and use .value. We can use document.getElementById() to do that.

Add .value to access the user input in the select field.

Make sure to pick ., followed by value.

lessons.title: Using the value
lessons.interactiveContent:
After accessing user selection, we can use it like any other value.

Try running your code and selecting an option to see what displays.

Make sure to pick ., followed by value.

lessons.title: Updating
lessons.interactiveContent:
Knowing how to get user input, we can use it to update a webpage.

Assemble the code so that the selected option from the ageSelect dropdown appears on the webpage when clicking on the Register button.

Make sure to pick .innerHTML, followed by =, and finally selected.

lessons.title: Disabled
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we add the attribute disabled, the option will be shown but can't be selected.

Make sure to pick disabled.

lessons.title: Selected + Disabled
lessons.interactiveContent:
When combining disabled with selected, the option will be selected by default but once it's changed, you can't select it again.

Make sure to pick selected.

lessons.title: Question #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why do we need a select element?

It allows us to give users a list of predefined options to choose fromIt's a more fancy way to receive text input from users

It allows us to give users a list of predefined options to choose from.

lessons.title: Question #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we access the selected value from the element?

.value.selectedIndex

Make sure to pick .value.

lessons.title: Question #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we disable an option?

By adding the attribute disabledBy removing the option

By adding the attribute disabled.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the attribute selected in combination with the attribute disabled do?

The option is selected by default, but users also can't change itThe option is hidden from the users

The option is selected by default, but users also can't change it.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set selectedOption to the selected option of the select element using .value.

Make sure to type .value.

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the content of the paragraph to selectedOption, the variable that stores the value of the select element.

Make sure to pick document.getElementById("message") followed by .innerHTML and then =, selectedOption.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Access the select element to display its value when clicking on the Submit button.

Make sure to pick "optionSelect".

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Access the selected option of the select element.

Make sure to pick value.

lessons.title: Example #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Ensure the option that's selected by default can't be chosen afterward.

Make sure to type disabled.
